title: 113_hr1929
content: The Act is titled the "Enhancing Employment and Training Through Education Act of 2013." It includes pilot projects to reduce dependency and increase work effort in the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program. Section 17 of the Food and Nutrition Act of 2008 is amended to include pilot projects aimed at increasing work effort and reducing dependency in the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program. The projects will identify best practices for employment and training programs to help participants secure unsubsidized employment, increase earned income, and decrease reliance on public assistance. Pilot projects will be selected based on criteria set by the Secretary, including enhancing existing programs and participating in evaluations of participants' employment activities. The pilot projects under the Food and Nutrition Act of 2008 aim to increase work effort and reduce dependency in the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program. Criteria for selecting projects include collaboration with job training programs, replicability, targeting various populations, and utilizing existing employment and training programs. The pilot projects aim to increase work effort and reduce dependency in the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program by selecting individuals from various employment and training programs in different geographic areas. The Secretary will conduct an independent evaluation of pilot projects under this subsection to measure their impact on participants' ability to find and retain employment leading to increased household income and reduced dependency. A report on the results of each pilot project must be submitted to Congress by September 30, 2017. The Secretary will conduct an evaluation of pilot projects to assess their impact on employment, income, and public benefits. $10,000,000 will be allocated annually for this purpose from 2014 to 2016. The Secretary will allocate $10,000,000 annually from 2014 to 2016 for pilot projects under subsection 18(a)(1). The funds are to be used for project compliance, administration, data provision, and evaluation costs. Non-Federal funds for existing employment and training activities cannot be replaced by these funds.
